title: Non-Variceal Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding
diagnosis_topic: Peptic ulcer disease causing upper GI bleeding
setup_script: A 65-year-old man presents with melena and lightheadedness. He takes NSAIDs for chronic knee pain. He denies alcohol use.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 95/60 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 36.9 C; patient pale and diaphoretic.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident secures two large-bore IVs and begins fluid resuscitation
dynamic_flow.reply: Administer crystalloid followed by transfusion to maintain Hgb >7 g/dL.
CBC, coagulation profile, type and cross; BUN elevated disproportionately to creatinine suggesting upper GI source.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident starts IV proton pump inhibitor infusion
dynamic_flow.reply: Esomeprazole bolus followed by continuous infusion to stabilize clot.
Large-bore NG tube placed; aspirate reveals coffee-ground material confirming upper GI source.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults gastroenterology for urgent endoscopy
dynamic_flow.reply: Endoscopy shows bleeding duodenal ulcer; epinephrine injection and hemoclip placed achieving hemostasis.
Not necessary for non-variceal bleed; indicated for variceal bleeding.
Interventional radiology for arterial embolization or surgical oversewing of ulcer considered.
Higher risk of rebleeding and mortality.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident tests for Helicobacter pylori
dynamic_flow.reply: Send biopsy or stool antigen; start eradication therapy if positive.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident counsels on NSAID cessation and PPI maintenance
dynamic_flow.reply: Discontinue NSAIDs; start long-term PPI therapy; consider COX-2 inhibitors with caution.
Use Rockall or Glasgow-Blatchford score to determine level of care and discharge timing.

critical_decision_points: Hemodynamic stabilization and resuscitation in upper GI bleeding
Use of IV PPI and early endoscopy for diagnosis and therapy
Differentiation between variceal and non-variceal sources
Management options if endoscopic therapy fails
Long-term management including H. pylori eradication and NSAID avoidance
